posts.name: priderobotics
posts.cooked: We‚Äôve built a modified H-drive, with 2 AndyMark Swerve and Steer modules attached to a KOP chassis, each in the middle of the side of the chassis. In each of the 4 corners, we have a passive omni wheel, all parallel. We‚Äôve never seen it done before, but it would sure save a lot of space and weight if it works. Anyone have any predictions? Thoughts, concerns, warnings?

posts.name: Nick Lawrence
posts.cooked:
Do you have a picture to share? This sounds pretty cool and unique.

-Nick

posts.name: Peyton Yeung
posts.cooked:
priderobotics:

In each of the 4 corners, we have a passive omni wheel, all parallel.

By passive do you mean unpowered? If so, one potential downside I can see is that the driven swerve modules would only be getting 1/3 the robot weight as normal force (i.e less traction).

I agree with Nick, that a picture would neat. This is a fairly unique idea and there is a little more discussion in this thread .

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: It may be a bit under powered with only 2 drive motors.  Most drivetrains have 4 and some have 6.  But if it works for you then go for it.

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôm pretty sure FTC Team 1115 Gluten Free did this in 2019 as on offseason project:

Still very cool that you modded a kitbot chassis though

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.custom_user_title: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
While it is very unlikely in this game, getting the front or rear unpowered wheels off the carpet may result in the powered wheels not getting grip. You‚Äôd need a hefty drop-center to make sure this doesn‚Äôt happen.

The power cables running under the Center Line on one side of the field is less than 1" tall, so momentum would likely carry you over it.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
priderobotics:

Swerve and Steer modules attached to a KOP chassis, each in the middle of the side of the chassis. In each of the 4 corners, we have a passive omni wheel

The advantage of swerve over holonomic (mecanum or omni) drive systems is that you can use all of your robot‚Äôs weight times the CoF of your wheels to deliver drive force.  ‚ÄúPassive‚Äù wheels give up whatever weight is on them.    So you get the headaches and high maintenance of swerve, with the disadvantages of holonomic.  Of course, if you‚Äôre going for cool factor on a budget, carry on!

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: You may have trouble in pushing matches though if their bumpers get under yours and lift the front of the frame

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.name: Orion DeYoe
posts.cooked: A potential solution to the ‚Äúlosing contact with the floor issue‚Äù is to move the modules to two opposite corners and only have 2 omnis (in the other two corners).  That also gets a larger fraction of the weight on the driven wheels.
